titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: The Socialist candidate has been returned to Eastham, through the intervention of a liberal candidate. The actual vote for Socialism was smaller than at the General Election. I spent the whole day indoors, for rain began to fall shortly after breakfast, and continued to fall in varying degrees of violence until the evening. I wrote something more of the Article for the Bishoprick, and pledged mine host to take in that journal. Lady S. begged me to preach in the Chapel on Sunday, and I promised to do so though I have no robes with me. The Vicar, who acts as Chaplain came to see me. He is an ex–naval Chaplain. I spent the afternoon in reading a painfully interesting & powerfully written Russian War–novel.

Hadow arrived before dinner bringing with him a breeze of optimism & confidence. He spoke to Lloyd George, of whose essential disinterestedness & patriotism he is fully persuaded. His great fault is an excessive belief in his own powers of reconciliation, & thus, in Hadow's view, explained his worst failures. As one of his best friends phased it, Lloyd George was "too fond of harnessing the devil". Hadow refuses to take the proceedings at Scarborough seriously. But herein I must judge him to be mistaken.
